extendedIngredients.name: beets
extendedIngredients.original: 2 large beets with their green tops (about 1 pound total)
extendedIngredients.originalName: beets with their green tops (about 1 pound total)
meta: with their green tops ( 1 pound total)

extendedIngredients.name: curry leaves
extendedIngredients.original: 6 to 8 medium to large fresh curry leaves
extendedIngredients.originalName: to 8 medium to large fresh curry leaves

extendedIngredients.name: ginger
extendedIngredients.original: 3 lengthwise slices fresh ginger (each 2 inches long. 1 inch wide, and 1/8 inch thick), cut into matchstick-thin strips (julienne)
extendedIngredients.originalName: lengthwise slices fresh ginger (each 2 inches long. 1 inch wide, and 1/8 inch thick), cut into matchstick-thin strips (julienne)

extendedIngredients.name: sea salt
extendedIngredients.original: 1 teaspoon coarse kosher or sea salt

extendedIngredients.name: serrano chiles
extendedIngredients.original: 2 fresh Thai, cayenne, or serrano chiles, stems removed, cut in half lengthwise (do not remove the seeds)
extendedIngredients.originalName: fresh Thai, cayenne, or serrano chiles, stems removed, cut in half lengthwise (do not remove the seeds)
meta: cut in half lengthwise (do not remove the seeds)

extendedIngredients.name: yellow mustard seeds
extendedIngredients.original: 1 teaspoons black or yellow mustard seeds

title: Cook the Book: Stewed Beets with Beet Greens and Ginger
summary: You can never have too many soup recipes, so give Cook the Book: Stewed Beets with Beet Greens and Ginger a try. This gluten free, whole 30, and vegan recipe serves 4 and costs 41 cents per serving. One serving contains 89 calories, 1g of protein, and 7g of fat. If you have beets, serrano chiles, lengthwise ginger, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. 1 person has made this recipe and would make it again. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes about 45 minutes. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 38%. This score is not so awesome. Try Cook the Book: Stewed Onions with Marjoram, Stewed Beet Greens, and Cook the Book: Magee's Roast Turkey, Parsley Potatoes, and Stewed Zucchini for similar recipes.
instructions: Procedures                                                                              1                                                                            Separate the greens from the beet bulbs (you can cut them off or twist, yank, and tear them away-whatever your state of mind).  Rinse the greens under cold running water and shake off the excess water.  Arrange the greens in a stack on the cutting board and slice the bunch into thin shreds-including the deep red, juicy stalks,  Transfer them into a small bowl.  Trim off  and discard both ends of each beet bulb.  Peel them with a vegetable peeler, and rinse then under running water.  Cut the bulbs into 1-inch cubes.                                                                                                                            2                                                                            Heat the oil in a medium-size saucepan over medium-high heat.  Add the mustard seeds, cover the pan, and cook until the seeds have stopped popping (not unlike popcorn), about 30 seconds.  Add the beets, curry leaves, and chiles.  Stir-fry to coat the red beets with the mustard seeds, 1 to 2 minutes.  Then reduce the heat to medium-low, cover the pan, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the beets are braised, 10 to 15 minutes.  (The beets will sweat, releasing some liquid, in which they will cook.)                                                                                                                            3                                                                            Add the beet greens, salt, ginger, and 1 cup water.  Once the blood-red curry comes to a boil, cover the pan and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the beets have absorbed most of the liquid and are tender when tested (or more appropriately, tasted), 25 to 30 minutes.  Then serve.

steps.step: Separate the greens from the beet bulbs (you can cut them off or twist, yank, and tear them away-whatever your state of mind).  Rinse the greens under cold running water and shake off the excess water.  Arrange the greens in a stack on the cutting board and slice the bunch into thin shreds-including the deep red, juicy stalks,
Transfer them into a small bowl.  Trim off  and discard both ends of each beet bulb.  Peel them with a vegetable peeler, and rinse then under running water.
Heat the oil in a medium-size saucepan over medium-high heat.
Add the mustard seeds, cover the pan, and cook until the seeds have stopped popping (not unlike popcorn), about 30 seconds.

Add the beets, curry leaves, and chiles.  Stir-fry to coat the red beets with the mustard seeds, 1 to 2 minutes.  Then reduce the heat to medium-low, cover the pan, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the beets are braised, 10 to 15 minutes.  (The beets will sweat, releasing some liquid, in which they will cook.)

Add the beet greens, salt, ginger, and 1 cup water.  Once the blood-red curry comes to a boil, cover the pan and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the beets have absorbed most of the liquid and are tender when tested (or more appropriately, tasted), 25 to 30 minutes.  Then serve.
